content: Some fibers, such as jute, kenaf, and flax, have the potential to save resources, as do synthetic alternatives for products such as rubber.

sections.name: Fiber Crops
content: The life cycle implications of three plants for producing fiber crops are as follows.
Flax fibers can be a substitute for glass fibers, saving overall environmental impact.
!Source: van Dam and Bos [flax_glass]. Impacts are measured in thousands of a 'point' (millipoints, or mPt), a measure that aggregates several environmental impacts into a single figure.

sections.name: Textile Fiber
content: Among fibers commonly used for clothing, silk generally has the greatest environmental impact.

!Source: [fiber_lca2]. Reported figures are the range across several life cycle assessments for producing the various fibers. Above, 'rayon' and 'other plastics' are the aggregations of several other categories.
Organic cotton generally has lesser impacts than conventional cotton.

sections.name: Rubber
content: Rubber, most commonly harvested from the plant Hevea brasiliensis [hevea], is a widely used polymer, about half of which is used for tires [rubber_use]. The life cycle impacts of producing rubber have been estimated as follows.
Synthetic (vulcanized) rubber is not used today for truck tires, due to its inferior abrasion properties, but this may change with newly discovered techniques [rubber_truck].
